title: ‘There’s a kid breaking racquets, smashing them’
text:
Jelena Dokic on Roger Federer: From ‘kid with the crazy temper’ to icon in another Aus Open semi 2 minutes ago by Jelena Dokic Source: FOX SPORTS “THERE’S a kid breaking racquets, smashing them. He’s broken six of them on the court.” 
I remember someone telling me this when I was a junior at Wimbledon in 1998 and I kept hearing about this kid with the crazy temper, just going mental on the court. 
It turns out it was Roger Federer. 
Nowadays Roger as one of the calmest players on the court but it’s well-know that he wasn’t always that way. 
We played juniors together at the same time and we were voted the ITF’s No.1 juniors together for the 1998 season. 
The talk was often about Roger’s temper back then but he was also really nice off-court and you could see his talent and technique early on. 
The way he was able to turn that around so dramatically and get control of these issues before turning pro is just another reason why he’s one of the greatest ever, not just as a tennis player but as a person. 
What we’ve seen him do at the Australian Open this week is just incredible, although probably not that surprising when it comes to Roger. Roger Federer at Wimbledon in 2000. Picture: Clive Brunskill /Allsport Source: Getty Images 
‘WHAT YOU SEE IS WHAT YOU GET’ 
While I obviously haven’t had much to do with Roger in recent years our paths crossed quite a bit earlier on in our careers. 
I saw him in juniors a little bit but he was also at the Hopman Cup in 1999, the year I won it with Mark Philippoussis. Roger was there with his Australian coach Peter Carter, who has sadly since died. 
I remember watching him practice and you could tell, with his technique and everything, that he was special. 
The other thing that sticks out in my mind is that he was always there watching the other matches, even the women’s matches and some of mine. You could tell he really loved tennis. 
He was really nice to me back then and always has been since. 
That’s the thing with Roger, what you see is what you get. There’s no act about it and the way you see him on TV, on court or in interviews, that’s really him Fed wins top shelf rally 0:46 
‘MACHINE-LIKE’ 
Many people think of Roger as somewhat of a late bloomer and forget how good of a junior he was. He won the Wimbledon boys title in 1998 and made the US Open final the same year. 
He also knew he need to get on top of his emotions and he did that. A lot of players have matured and developed in that way but he has been able to do it to another level because he was quite extreme. 
Now, he’s become one of the calmest guys on the court. You will never see anything negative. His body language is incredible and mentally and emotionally, he’s so stable and so strong. 
Some players are never able to change that sort of thing on-court - and to not show emotion - and I don’t think it’s necessarily a bad thing. Someone like Goran Ivanisevic comes to mind. Everybody was so entertained by that and, while it’s not always the best thing to do on court, that was him and everyone is individual. 
But Roger has been able to turn himself into a machine-like player because he’s been able to deal with it. Yes, you mature as you get older but he actually worked hard on that and made sure that didn’t affect his tennis. Roger Federer hits a return against Mischa Zverev. Source: AFP 
‘IT WILL BE TOUGH AGAINST STAN’ 
I believe Roger when he says he really didn’t expect to do this well at the Australian Open. 
Given the injury problems he had last year, he’s really happy just to be back and I think it means a lot for him just to be playing, win or lose. 
To not just be in the semi-finals, but beating Tomas Berdych and Kei Nishikori to get there, is pretty incredible. To display the level of tennis he’s displayed, especially for someone coming off a six-month break, not a lot of people can do that. 
It’s really special and I think all of us are hoping - nothing against the other players – that he can get to the final and win it. 
The reality is it’s going to be very tough against Stan Wawrinka. Roger has a great head-to-head record against Stan and mentally he probably does have a bit of an edge. 
But Stan has been going under the radar, not a lot of people have been talking about him which is surprising because he won the US Open, the last grand slam played. 
I actually think, even though Roger has played so well, he’s probably not the favourite in this match. It’s going to come down to how both guys play on the day. 
A lot of people are starting to talk about the prospect of a Federer vs Rafael Nadal final and that would be incredible, a dream final really. 
It won’t be easy for Rafa to make it there either but with these two legends of the game, I certainly wouldn’t write it off. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
